Award.AwardTitle: A Reference Grammar of Choguita Raramuri (Tarahumara) [ISO 639-3: tar]

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Choguita Rar√°muri (CR; Tarahumara) is an endangered, underdescribed Uto-Aztecan language spoken in northern Mexico, an area where a significant number of languages became extinct without any documentation before the eighteenth century. With its complex morphology, CR provides a unique opportunity to explore critical questions about the nature of the phonology-morphology interface, the interplay between psycholinguistic and distributional factors in agglutinating morphological systems, as well as the reconstruction of the linguistic and cultural past of the Americas. Initial documentation efforts carried out in the past decade have produced a representative sample of video and audio recordings of a wide range of speech genres. This project will quantitatively and qualitatively expand the existing corpus in order to deepen description and analysis of the language towards the completion of a grammatical description of the language. Through language documentation that is increasingly controlled, modeled and produced by community members, the project will provide: (1) a reference grammar linked to an annotated corpus; (2) an analysis of the typologically unusual morphologically conditioned phonological processes of this language; (3) an assessment of the variation in the linguistic structures within the CR speech community, including variation between older, mostly monolingual speakers, and younger, bilingual speakers; and (4) a corpus of transcribed and annotated audio and visual documents available to community members to serve in efforts of reversal of language decline. The annotated corpus will allow conducting novel theoretical studies on the phonological cues of morphological structure in this agglutinating language. As such, this project will contribute to initiating studies of sophisticated and fine-grained phonological and morphological properties in under-described languages of the Americas with similar morphological systems. Both graduate students and undergraduates are involved in this research, and the research will foster the community's efforts to revitalize and fortify language use through involvement of community members. In addition, the research will be of value to understanding the history of land use in the area, a topic that has attracted recent attention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Choguita Raramuri (Tarahumara) language project was carried out over several years in collaboration with a team of US-based students and community members. This collaborative project led to the collection of a large quantity of Choguita Raramuri linguistic data, and developed linguistic analyses and language documentation for a wide range of uses by linguists, academics in associated fields, and community members. Choguita Raramuri is a Uto-Aztecan language spoken in Northern Mexico, an area that has been affected by severe political violence and economic downturn in the last few decades. While there are still relatively large numbers of speakers of this language and related varieties, this language is endangered given the economic, social and political pressures that the Raramuri speech communities face. The main products stemming from this project include a draft of a reference grammar of the language that will be published as a book, a set of publications on the language (some of which are co-authored with community members and/or US-based students), a large corpus of recordings, as well as the development of tools for the development of language documentation corpora to be used by other academics and members of speech communities world-wide.

Documentation and analysis of Choguita Raramuri is important for both scientific and humanistic reasons that give this project broader social impact. Scientifically, documentation, description, and analysis of Choguita Raramuri gives us important insights about the nature of the sound patterns and word structures or the world?s languages, as well as how speakers of morphologically complex languages process this information. Similar questions have been addressed for English and other better-known languages, but data from under-documented and endangered languages with significantly different grammatical structures had not been addressed in the theoretical and typological literature. The data and analysis from Choguita Raramuri give us crucial insights into the way sound patterns and word structures interact in any given language. In addition, the close analysis of the sound system (phonology) and grammar (morphology and syntax) of the language has yielded specific insights into the structure of the language that will contribute to developments in other aspects of linguistic theory, and to our understanding of the history of the Uto-Aztecan language family and indigenous languages of the Americas more generally. In terms of its broader humanistic impacts, this project has contributed relevant documentation of an endangered language and, through a collaborative approach, produced resources for a speech community who seeks to develop its own language record in a broad cultural and historical context. The project also trained community members in video recording, who developed their own documentation materials and implemented them in novel ways in the local school in order to revalorize and promote the language and the broader cultural legacy of the community. US-based students involved in the project received significant training in linguistic analysis, language documentation and development of collaborations with speech communities using new tools and methodologies within the field of linguistics.

Primary data collection and analysis was carried out over several months of field research over the multi-year project in Northern Mexico, involving close collaboration between the PI, US-based students and community members interested in the linguistic analysis and documentation of their language. Further focused analysis and data-processing was carried out at UCSD.

The data collected for this project included a large number or digital audio and video recordings of CR language use, including traditional mythical narratives, shamanic songs and prayers, community and personal histories, and everyday conversations, as well as controlled elicited data using experimental and more traditional qualitative linguistic methods. A portion of the recordings have been transcribed, and annotated; data has also contributed to the development of a lexical database and a collection of texts which will be available in an open-access user-interface that allows to search for data in a way that can be customized for both academic audiences and community members. The elicited grammatical data includes sentences and word forms, as well as carefully recorded utterances used for phonetic analysis. This significant corpus of materials served as the basis for analyses and grammatical descriptions on a range of topics, including morphologically conditioned phonological patterns, the lexical and grammatical tone systems of the language, the morphosyntax and semantics of complex predicate constructions, variable affix ordering on verbs, valence-changing operations, the grammar of spatial expressions, among other topics.

All materials and data collected by the Choguita Raramuri Language Project, as well as grammatical descriptions written during fieldwork, are archived at UC Berkeley's Survey of California and Other Indian Languages archive and are available to scholars and community members who wish to learn about the grammar and lexicon of this language, as well as the oral traditions and history of its speakers. Materials have also been delivered to participant community members and are available for their use in the community of Choguita.
